Class SinglePriorityQueue<T extends Comparable<T>>

java.lang.Object
cp213.SingleLink<T>
cp213.SinglePriorityQueue<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the SingleNode data type
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<T>
public class SinglePriorityQueue<T extends Comparable<T>> extends SingleLink<T>
A single linked priority queue structure of T objects. These data objects must be Comparable - i.e. they must provide the compareTo method. Only the T data at the front of the priority queue is visible through the standard priority queue methods. Extends the SingleLink class.
Version:
2025-09-07
Author:
your name, id, email here

  • Constructor Details

    • SinglePriorityQueue

      public SinglePriorityQueue()

  • Method Details

    • combine

      public void combine(SinglePriorityQueue<T> left, SinglePriorityQueue<T> right)
      Combines the contents of left and right into this. Moves nodes only - does not refer to data in any way, or call the high-level methods insert or remove. left and right are empty when done. Nodes are moved such that they are inserted in order into this. May call any appropriate SingleLink helper methods available. left and right are not necessarily the same length. this must be empty at start, or the method throws an AssertionError. (This significantly simplifies the code.)
      Parameters:
      left - the first SingleQueue to extract nodes from
      right - the second SingleQueue to extract nodes from

    • insert

      public void insert(T datum)
      Adds object to this. Data is stored in priority order, with highest priority object at the front of this, and lowest at the rear. Priority is determined by simple comparison - lower valued objects have higher priority. For example, 1 has a higher priority than 2. (Think of the phrase, "We're number one!" as an indication of priority.)

      When inserting object int the priority queue, the queue must remain sorted. Hence you need to find the proper location for the inserted object.

      Parameters:
      datum - object to insert in sorted order in priority queue

    • remove

      public T remove()
      Removes and returns the highest priority object in this, which is located at the front node. Decrements the count.
      Returns:
      the highest priority object currently in this or null if this is empty

    • splitByKey

      public void splitByKey(T key, SinglePriorityQueue<T> higher, SinglePriorityQueue<T> lower)
      Splits the contents of this into higher and lower. Moves nodes only - does not move data or call the high-level methods insert or remove. this is empty when done. Nodes with priority object higher than key are moved to higher. Nodes with a priority object lower than or equal to key are moved to lower.
      Parameters:
      key - object to compare against node objects in SinglePriorityQueue
      higher - an initially empty SinglePriorityQueue queue that ends up with all objects with priority higher than key
      lower - an initially empty SinglePriorityQueue queue that ends up with all objects with priority lower than or equal to key
